title: 105_hr4431
content: The "HIV Partner Protection Act" is cited as the short title. It amends the Public Health Service Act to include a section on partner notification for HIV health care services. The "HIV Partner Protection Act" amends the Public Health Service Act to require States to implement partner notification programs for individuals with HIV disease. The "HIV Partner Protection Act" mandates that positive HIV test results be reported confidentially to the State public health officer, including the individual's name and necessary information. The program ensures partners are informed of potential exposure to HIV disease. The "HIV Partner Protection Act" mandates confidential reporting of positive HIV test results to the State public health officer without disclosing the infected individuals' identity. Counseling and testing for HIV, including information on transmission modes and therapeutic measures, are provided to partners and infected individuals. The "HIV Partner Protection Act" mandates confidential reporting of positive HIV test results to the State public health officer without disclosing the infected individuals' identity. Referrals for appropriate services are provided to partners and infected individuals, and notifications are provided in person. There are no penalties for infected individuals who choose not to identify their partners. The "HIV Partner Protection Act" allows for confidential reporting of positive HIV test results to the State public health officer without disclosing the infected individuals' identity. There are no penalties for individuals who choose not to identify their partners. Good faith errors in reporting are not penalized. The "HIV Partner Protection Act" allows for confidential reporting of positive HIV test results to the State public health officer without disclosing the infected individuals' identity. States can provide notification without the consent of the infected individual. State insurance laws must demonstrate compliance for receiving grants. The "HIV Partner Protection Act" requires State insurance laws to prohibit insurers from taking action against individuals who have been tested for HIV disease. This ensures confidentiality and protection for those who undergo testing. The "HIV Partner Protection Act" defines terms like 'infected individual' as someone with HIV disease and 'partner' as including spouses, sexual partners, and needle-sharing partners at risk of HIV. The "HIV Partner Protection Act" includes provisions for individuals at risk of HIV disease, including partners exposed to HIV. Certain states have delayed applicability of the requirements until fiscal year 2001 and subsequent years. The "HIV Partner Protection Act" authorizes grants to States for partner notification program costs related to HIV. $10,000,000 is authorized for each fiscal year from 2000 to 2004.
